Mulongo and the 
 ogre 
 
 Fabian Wakholi 
 English 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 A long time ago, there lived a man caled 
 Mulongo and his wife Nambuya. They 
 had two children, Mukhwana and 
 
 Namono. There was a famine in the land 
 where they lived. Al the vilagers, 
 including Mulongo and his family, would 
 
 leave their homes early to lok for fod 
 in the forest. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 One day, Mulongo, his wife and children
 decided to go dep in the forest in
 search of something to eat. From
 
 morning to evening they loked for fod
 but they found nothing. Nambuya urged
 her husband to go further into the forest.
 
 Mulongo led the way as Nambuya and
 the two children folowed. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 2  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Sudenly Mulongo saw a beautiful 
 
 banana plantation. He caled his wife and 
 said, “Is that not a banana plantation? I 
 
 can se bananas and other fod crops. I 
 wonder whose it is.” They moved on and 
 son saw a house in the midle of the 
 
 plantation. They stoped, loked in al 
 directions, but there was no one around. 
 
 Because they were hungry and it was 
 nearly night time, they decided to sit and 
 wait for the owner. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 3  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Sudenly they heard heavy breathing 
 close to the house. They were frightened 
 to se a huge ogre arive. “Who are you 
 
 and what do you want?” asked the ogre 
 in a fearful voice. Mulongo in a trembling 
 voice said, “We came loking for fod 
 
 because there is famine in our place.” 
 The ogre gave them fod. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 4  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 For several days the ogre alowed 
 Mulongo and his family to eat his crops 
 
 without asking for anything in return. One 
 morning, however, the ogre said to 
 Nambuya, “I want you to cok your son 
 
 for me to eat when I come back this 
 evening.” When the ogre had gone 
 Mulongo went into the bush and kiled 
 
 some smal animals, which he asked his 
 wife to cok for the ogre. Meanwhile he 
 
 asked Mukhwana to climb up a leafy 
 mango tre and hide. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 5  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 In the evening the ogre returned and
 asked, “Have you coked Mukhwana for
 
 me?” Mulongo’s wife answered, “Yes.”
 She gave the ogre the meat and he
 gredily ate everything. Then he said,
 
 “Tomorow you cok your daughter.”
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 6  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The folowing morning Mulongo and his 
 
 wife did as they had done on the first 
 day. Namono was hiden up the mango 
 tre. When the ogre returned he said, 
 
 “Did you cok Namono?” Again, 
 Nambuya told the ogre that she had 
 
 done so. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 7  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 After eating, the ogre instructed
 Nambuya to cok her husband Mulongo,
 the next day. Nambuya was perturbed
 
 but Mulongo said he would go out again
 and catch some animals to cok. He did
 that and after giving the meat to his wife,
 
 he also climbed up the mango tre to
 hide. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 8  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 At dusk the ogre came back. Nambuya 
 gave the meat to the ogre who enjoyed it 
 
 very much. He told Nambuya, “Tomorow 
 cok yourself.” When the ogre had left 
 Nambuya caled her husband to advise 
 
 her. Mulongo said, “Go and lok for some 
 smal animals and cok them for the 
 
 ogre. When everything is ready, come up 
 the tre where we are.” 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 9  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The ogre came back in the afternon and
 started eating his tasty evening meal of
 
 swet meat. 
 He felt slepy, went to lie under the
 mango tre and began snoring. But not
 
 so long after, the ogre woke up because
 he heard noises above him. The ogre
 
 loked up to the tre and saw Mulongo
 and his wife and children. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 10  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 WThe ogre was very angry. “So you 
 deceived me? Let me come and get you,” 
 he shouted. 
 
 As the ogre was strugling to climb up 
 the tre, Mulongo quickly thought of a 
 trick and said, “It wil be easier for you to 
 
 reach us if you tie a rope around your 
 neck and we help to pul you up.” 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The ogre ran into the house, brought a 
 
 strong rope and after tying it around his 
 neck he threw the other end of the rope 
 to Mulongo. Mulongo and his wife and 
 
 children started puling the ogre up as 
 they twisted the rope. The rope son 
 tightened around the ogre’s neck until he 
 
 could not breathe and died. Mulongo and 
 his family came down the tre and tok 
 
 over the ogre’s house and property.
